question.title: How to skip a number of lines when writing to a txt file

node.contents: Note that file systems in general do not support editing files in random places; you can't go to line number N and for example insert a new line there (or overwrite existing line N). You can, however, append data to the end of an existing file.

astNode.text: Note that file systems in general do not support editing files in random places; you can't go to line number N and for example insert a new line there (or overwrite existing line N). You can, however, append data to the end of an existing file.

node.contents: I'm making a program that will output lines to a text file. I don't wish to overwrite the file, but that is what my current code does. I just want to go down the number of lines that are already there and write hello. Here is my code:

astNode.text: I'm making a program that will output lines to a text file. I don't wish to overwrite the file, but that is what my current code does. I just want to go down the number of lines that are already there and write hello. Here is my code:

elements.contents: FileWriter fileWriter = new FileWriter(fileLocation, false); BufferedWriter bufferedWriter = new BufferedWriter(fileWriter); while(numberOfLines > compareToNumOfLines) { bufferedWriter.newLine(); compareToNumOfLines++; } bufferedWriter.write("hello"); bufferedWriter.close();

units.rawText: FileWriter fileWriter = new FileWriter(fileLocation, false); BufferedWriter bufferedWriter = new BufferedWriter(fileWriter); while(numberOfLines > compareToNumOfLines) { bufferedWriter.newLine(); compareToNumOfLines++; } bufferedWriterwrite("hello"); bufferedWriterclose();

node.contents: Unfortunately, this just creates spaces where the text used to be. What am I doing wrong?

astNode.text: Unfortunately, this just creates spaces where the text used to be. What am I doing wrong?

node.contents: I LOVE U SOOOO MUCH! thank you bro

astNode.text: I LOVE U SOOOO MUCH! thank you bro

node.contents: As explained in the documentation, the second argument is a boolean that specify if you want to append the text or overwrite it.

astNode.text: As explained in the documentation, the second argument is a boolean that specify if you want to append the text or overwrite it.

node.contents: If you want to append text to existing file then open the file in append mode. If you want to write at random place in file then you can use RandomAccessFile class.

astNode.text: If you want to append text to existing file then open the file in append mode. If you want to write at random place in file then you can use RandomAccessFile class.
